results.title: Early Communication in Australia
results.brief_description: Challenged to create a moving image work on the theme ‘Pacific Explorer’, this highly commended work uses Australian stamps with historical and Aboriginal themes to narrate the methods and ways Australians have communicated over time. An animated short entered to “Create a Stamp Story” section of ACMI’s ‘Screen It’ media making competition for Primary Schools.

results.title: Early cinema. Vol. 02
results.creator_credit: Hepworth Manufacturing Company, Cricks and Martin, Kineto Production Company and Edison Manufacturing Company
results.brief_description: Selected and compiled by the British Film Institute Film and Video Library, this 2 part series on early cinema presents a variety of films from the pre-1910 period. The selection tries to represent issues that are currently written about and refutes claims that “primitive” filmmaking was a series of progressive movements towards classic narrative cinema. Titles from the Hepworth Manufactury Company include: “How it feels to be run over” (dir. Cecil Hepworth); “Explosion of a motor car” (dir. Hepworth); “Rescued by Rover” (dirs. Lewin Fitzhamon and possibly Hepworth); “The Other side of the hedge” (dir. Fitzhamon); “That fatal sneeze” (dir. Fitzhamon). Titles from the Cricks and Martin Studio include: “A Visit to Peek Frean and Co.’s biscuit works”. Titles from the Kineto Production Company include: “A Day in the life of a coalminer”. Titles from the Pathe Freres studio include: “Par le trou de serrure (Peeping Tom)”; “Histoire d’un crime” (dir. Ferdinand Zecca); Ali Baba et les quarante voleurs” (dir. Zecca); “Reve et realite (dir. possibly Zecca); “La Revolution en Russie (Les Evenements d’Odessa/Le cuirasse Potemkine/Revolution in Odessa)” (dir. Lucien Nouquet); “Aladin ou la lampe merveilleuse”; “Le Cheval emballe” (dir. Zecca); “The Physican of the castle”; “Magic bricks” (dir. Gaston Velle). Titles from the Edison Manufacturing Company include: “Dewar’s - it’s scotch”; “The Gay shoe clerk” (dir. Edwin s Porter); “The Great train robbery” (dir. Porter); and “The Dream of a rarebit fiend”. A voiceover provides a brief overview of each production studio prior, and during the presentation of films the studio has produced. Piano accompaniment by Neil Brand.

results.title: Early cinema. Vol. 01
results.creator_credit: Lumière, Melies, Acres, R.W. Paul, George Albert Smith Films, Sheffield Photographic Company, Haggar and Sons, Bamforth and Company Ltd and Williamson's Kinematograph Company Ltd
results.brief_description: Selected and compiled by the British Film Institute Film and Video Library, this 2 part series on early cinema presents a variety of films from the pre-1910 period. The selection tries to represent issues that are currently written about and refutes claims that “primitive” filmmaking was a series of progressive movements towards classic narrative cinema. Titles from the Lumiere studios include: “Sortie d’usine”; “Repas de bebe”; “Demolition d’un mur”; “Le Jardinier et le petit espiegle (L’Arroseur arrose)”; “Arrivee des Congressistes a Neuville-sur-Saone”; “Arrivee d’un train en gare a La Ciotat”; “Partie d’ecarte”; “Barque sortant du port”; “Leaving Jerusalem by railway”; “Bataille de boules de neige”; “Pompiers a Lyon”; “Niagra”; “Spanish bullfight”. Titles from the Melies studio include: “Voyage a travers l’impossible”. Titles from the Acres studio include: “Rough sea at dover”. Titles from the R.W. Paul studio include: “Come along do!”; “The Derby”; “The Countryman and the cinematograph”; “A Chess dispute”; “Extraordinary cab accident”; “Buy your own cherries”; “The ? Motorist”. Titles from the George Albert Smith Films studio include: “The Miller and the sweep”; “The Kiss in the tunnel”; “Let me dream again”; “Grandma’s reading glass”; “As seen through a telescope”; “Sick kitten”; “Mary Jane’s mishap, or don’t fool with paraffin (Here lies Mary Jane who lighted the fire with paraffin)”. Titles from the Sheffield Photographic Company include: “Daring daylight burglary”. Titles from the Haggar and Sons studio include: “Desperate poaching affray”. Titles from the Bamforth and Company Ltd include: “The Kiss in the tunnel”; “Ladies skirts nailed to a fence”; “The Bitter bit (aka A Joke on the gardener)”; “Rough sea”. Titles from Williamson’s Kinematograph Company Ltd include: “Attack on a China mission”; “The Big swallow”; “Stop thief”; “Fire”; “An Interesting story”. A voiceover provides a brief overview of each production studio prior, and during the presentation of films the studio has produced. Piano accompaniment by Neil Brand.

results.title: Early childhood
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Personality”.
The experiences of pre-school children play a role in all aspects of their personality development. While there are many personality traits developing during this age period, several are of special significance: dependence, identification, aggression, fear and anxiety.

results.title: Early American civilizations (Mayan, Aztec, Incan)
results.brief_description: A description of three important civilisations that flourished before the Spanish conquest in the new world - Mayan, Aztec and Incan. This film stresses the economic background shared by all three cultures, an economy based on corn. Shows Mayan carvings, the Teotihuacano’s Pyramid of the Sun, the Aztec calendar stone, Incan weavings and other art objects and ruins.

results.title: Early Amateur Sound Film (1936–37)
results.brief_description: Amateur filmmaker Archie Stewart used an RCA Sound Camera to document family life from 1935. A member of the Amateur Cinema League, in 1937 he published one of the first articles on amateur sound, ‘A Talkie Movie Maker Speaks’, in the league’s magazine.

constellations_other.name: Amateur hour
constellations_other.description: Early sound equipment allowed filmmakers and amateurs alike the ability to experiment often with affordable 16mm film.

results.title: Early actualities [Silent]
results.brief_description: This is a compilation of early short silent films made between 1900-1905 about newsworthy events. Each “short” is preceded by explanatory titles as follows: THE BOER WAR: DEPARTURE OF THE GORDON HIGHLANDERS (OCT. 1899); LORD ROBERTS ARRIVES IN CAPE TOWN (JAN.1900); STREET SCENE IN LEEDS (C.1903); SCENE ON BRIGHTON PIER (C.1898); FIRE BRIGADE SCENE IN BRITAIN, FRANCE AND U.S.A. (C.1896-1902); FUNERAL OF QUEEN VICTORIA (FEB.1901).

results.title: Early abortion
results.brief_description: Uses scenes from a question-and-answer session and from an abortion procedure in order to explain a typical atravmatic abortion procedure. Narrated by Adrienne Barbeau and animation by Robert Greenberg

results.title: Earliest times to 1066
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “English History”.
This film discusses the building of Anglo-Saxon England, with emphasis on the many different peoples and cultures which contribute to the development of the English nation. This film uses authentic landmarks and historical material from 1900 B.C. to 1000 A.D. as well as brief re-enactments of important historical events to give a compressed picture of England and its people before the Norman Conquest.
